tagDescription: Mount Hood on the Columbia River
The falls of the Grande Mere
Faint pencil sketch of a dog

Notebook entitled Private Diary & Journal Oregon Territory 1846, begun January 1846 and continuing until 16 June 1846, including some survey notes and plans. An inscription dates the notebook Fort Vancouver.. . January 1st 1846. Stamped pagination runs from the back of the notebook to the front. It does not correspond to the chronological sequence and it does not correspond to the page sequence as filmed.

Notebook entitled Moose Deer Hunting on the Snow up the three Rivers March 1842, with a list of participants. A descriptive narative of a moosehunt along the St. Maurice River, with sketches and watercolours.
Journal of a Trip to Saratoga Springs, August 1842. The inscription on the flyleaf is dated August 1842, Montreal.
descending a Mountain during the chase
Interior of the Squaws second & open Cabane
Camp on the Etchement River (Etchemin River)
crossing a waterfall on our return to Camp Rr des Rats
Hauling the Boat over the Rapids
Map of the Lake and its environs, near Port Neuf

Notebook entitled Winter travelling in Canada and the United States, a visit to Boston, New York, Philadelphia, Washington, and Charleston December 1842 - February 1843. Inserted in the notebook cover is an advertisement dated 1846 from Oregon City, soliciting articles for the newly founded Oregon Spectator.

Journal of an Expedition in search of Moose Deer on the St. Maurice River. .. March 1842, is an expanded version of the notebook, (vol. 6), with comments and sketches added to the text. Added material usually refers to geographical features, winter transportation such as snowshoeing, hunting techniques, Indian guides and lumbermen.

This volume includes another set of sketches (viewed from the back to the middle of the volume) entitled Sketches and Scraps in North America from 1839 to 1843. All dated illustrations, however, are of Upper and Lower Canada, 1840, and coincide with an inspection tour of that year (see volume 1 ).
Pencil notes with the endorsement Saratoga August 9th 1844.
Journal entitled Private Journal Columbia River  No. 3, August 1845.

Sketchbook of a hunting trip across the Western Prairies towards Santa Fe, Mexico, August-October 1840. Entitled Hunting Tour Western Prairies -  with a list of the participants. It contains sketches and watercolours.

Private Journal of a Canoe Voyage from Montreal to the Red River Settlement.. ..  May 1845. Included are two small maps and a sketch of the Red River settlement. Specific information on the military threat of the United States, a possible route for British troop movement, and the vulnerability of British forts and western settlements is written in pencil at the back of the journal. A history of the Red River Settlement is written from the back to the front of the journal, p. 932 (88) to p. 892 (105) on alternate pages. The stamped pagination does not correlate with the sequence of the original. A number of pages at the beginning of the journal were removed after use, Entries from May to 16 June remain. A later draft of these notes is found in the journal, Volume 22.

Journal entitled Private Diary of Events in the Oregan Territory 1846 (No. 5), begun 1 January 1846 and covering the return journey to Montreal. An inscription dates the journal Fort Vancouver Columbia River Oregan - January 1st 1846. The original pagination does not correspond to the stamped pagination, The first 8 pages were cut out.
Baie des Rochers, river de Quelle
Notebook describing travels from Cape Disappointment to Fort Victoria, illustrated with sketches. An inscription inside the back cover is dated  3 Sept. 1845, Vancouver.
Packet with the covering note Sketches taken en route to the Columbia River - Oregon 1845, consisting of pencil sketches, some of which are colour washed, and watercolours.
Tadoussac, Old Village on the Saguenay River
The St. Lawrence from Hare Islands
Fall up the River / at Port Neuf
Salmon Packing, Above the Cascades, on the Columbia

Journal of a Tour to the Far West is a descriptive narrative of the hunting trip across the prairies , August-October 1840. The inscription on the flyleaf dates the journal 1841, Montreal. The journal has editorial comments and corrections.
continuation of the Lake s.c. Pt. Neuf
Tour on the Western Prairies continued (2nd vol.) is a continuation of the descriptive narrative of the hunting trip, in volume 4.
The inscription on the flyleaf dates the journal 1841, Montreal. Included are editorial notes and corrections.

Journal entitled Voyage to and life in Canada. A descriptive narrative covering the voyage aboard the HMS. PIQUE 1839, and events in British North America and the United States to 1843. There is much social and cultural description and political observation.
Tomaqua's Cabane at Les Grandes Tantes
Distant View of the Rocky Mountains
Lake at the Head of the Columbia River

Private Journal & Notes on the Oregon Territory during a Winter Residence to the end of 1845 (No. 4). A descriptive narrative covering travels of August to 31 December 1845. There are editorial corrections throughout.
Landscape with Rocks and Fir Trees
The Camp seen from a hill

Journal entitled Trip to the Southern States 16 Dec. 1842 - February 1843. This descriptive narrative is an expanded version of the notebook, volume 9. A reference to the Civil War and a comment dated 1885 indicate a much later writing of this draft of Warre's journal.
the summer residence of His Exy The Comr of the Forces in B.N. America Sorel
The Mouth of the Saguenay River / 90 miles below Quebec - St. Lawrence Riv.
Lake at the head of the.. ..Columbia River
Notebook of a fishing trip on the lower Saguenay, entitled Fishing tour on board the Schooner Fanny ---below the Saguenay, River St. Lawrence 18401', illustrated with sketches.

Journal entitled Diary from the Red River Settlement.. ..to the Columbia River June-August 1845 (No. 2). A descriptive narrative illustrated with sketches. An obliterated section (pp. 1030-1032) may be read in a typescript accompanying the original.
